title: Enterprise search trends and challenges
segmentation: Everything we've seen up until now has been concerning web search and and my talk.
I'm going to explain about a different type of search.
Environment Key which is our enterprise search, so I'll talk about three things.
What enterprise search is what the difference between enterprise search and web searches and then talk about their needs and trends?
For Enterprise search, well enterprise Search has its own Wikipedia entries, so you can see what it is.
But essentially it means dealing with all the information that.
Inside a company.
Um, there's a big market for this, and I'll show why.
There's where this market comes from, so they consider to be 2.5 billion dollars about this market.
Now let me put this in perspective.
A lot of people mentioned Google as the elephant in the room.
People mention Google and.
In one way you could consider that Google is not a search company but an advertising company.
If you look on Google's financial pages, which they have on the website, you find that in 2007 Google has made 16.5 billion dollars of revenue.
And they divide up into two categories, the revenue from advertising and revenue from licensing, which is where our domain is.
The revenue from advertising is 16.4 billion dollars and they have 100 million dollars of revenue from licensing.
So the bulk of Google's income is from advertising.
So that's actually the most important business for Google.
And if we go down into the smaller.
Change the 2.5 billion dollar range.
Then there's lots of room for improving and dealing with this niche of search.
OK, the reason why Enterprise search exists as a niche at all is, for three reasons.
One is.
The amount of information that people have to deal with inside a company.
These estimates there will be almost 1000 exabytes of worldwide data and a lot of that data isn't data on the web, but it's inside inside, behind firewalls.
And another.
Automation is that.
In the company and employee will receive something like 40,000 emails per year.
Now this is important for companies in the US to store all these emails.
Everything that transits through the company has to be stored and searchable, and that's because of certain scandals like of Enron and certain laws which make that.
Email equivalent to paper documents.
So now businesses have to store.
A lot of information.
And businesses of course have a lot of vital information that they want to that they have to store that is currently storing databases, but they want to make this information.

Bailable to to their clients, so there's three reasons that there's a that they have to keep all the information they have that the people inside the company dealing with a lot of information, and the fact that we want to get information on the databases and be able to use a man search over them.
That's the whole reason why enterprise search exists as an.
In the domain.
And just one example of this last point of indexing.

There's a whole sub domain called database offloading, which means taking all the information in a database and offloading it, and then about putting it into the search index and that way the database controls just the writing and writing information and storing and protecting data.
But all the reading is done in an offloaded.
Index.
I'll get back to that.
So enterprise search deals with the massive information inside of an enterprise.
Now what's the difference between that massive information inside an enterprise and on the.
Well, First off, the enterprise is not just a small Internet.
Google sells these boxes which allow you to index your documents as if you had a small Internet.
And they're very good.
And they're modulable, and that's where they license.
Incomes come from.
But I'll show you some other differences that most of these differences come from an article you can find on the Internet called.
By Mark Bennett.
That did this stuff.
20 different differences by just show one few.
First off, I on an enterprise.
It's not web pages in web pages out since Google is dealing with web, it adapted to take web pages and it produces.
Pages, but as we saw this morning, I think those you mentioned that there's lots of different.

Event talk.

There's lots of different sources of information as emails as a World Wide Web, but there's also a lot of databases, file servers, desktops is images that are inside the firewall and there's enterprise resource management, so all this information is has to be indexed to, and it's not.
This web page is.

Doesn't work inside an enterprise because the idea of popularity.
Is not what's important.
When documents are inside the enterprise, even though they might not be used or linked by any other document, you have to get that information.
Back another difference is that web search deals with generic documents that might have this structure.
Here this is the type of structure.
People work on an information retrieval in the right hand side with a little bit of XML markup HTML markup.
But a lot of the documents inside an enterprise are.
This structured information.

Doesn't seem like it's in focus.
If it's not.
Anne.
And one of the reasons why Ricardo said that you can get a lot of information off the web is there, although not everything is annotated that lots of annotation.
So you can just take trends of things, whereas inside an enterprise you need immediate need to be much more precise.
You have to know exactly if there's bug reports coming.
You have to know exactly where the bugs are, so we need a lot more semantics about the info.
Nation being indexed.
Another difference between web search and.
And Enterprise search is web search is sort of this panning for gold type things.
You you send your query, often you get information back and you find things you like then that's good.
Whereas in enterprise search people using the search to perform a task at task for the for the job.
So tasks are often things that have built in structured overtime, and it turns out that what's being what's becoming most popular inside of enterprise search is being able to do faceted search.
And faceted search is something people becoming familiar with in shopping.
And my prediction is that this is going to be something something much more important.
Facet is things like if you're doing shopping, you say I want to.
I want to have Mens clothes and not women's clothes.
So you take all the data you put into Mens piles and then you say I want to have shirts.
So that's all the data in shirts and then you say you know what size you are and you're restricting the data down into smaller and smaller places.

This can be done because each one of those dimensions is a facet or a semantic dimension, so I'll say more about that later, but adding new semantic dimensions in and that's one of the particularity's of the exited search engine is something that will become more and more important.
Search if you saw the Tom Cruise movie with Minority Report.
He was manipulating things information visually and that's using facets.

Experience.
Another very important difference is inside as enterprise search users are identified and this is important.
It has advantages and disadvantages.
The disadvantage is that you have to be able to deal with all of the access control, so if someone can see a document then you can see it.
And if someone is not allowed to see your document because they're not, then you have to eliminate that document not only from the result set, but from the result list, and you have to.
You have to hide that so you have to deal with all these information about about permissions.
The advantages of it are that you can follow what somebody is doing throughout his throughout his query history, and that allows you to identify X.
Search within a company.
OK, another difference is since people inside companies are used to dealing with the databases, they want their output to look like this.
They want to have bar charts and graphs and things linked up to Maps.
Well this is this is common, often the Maps.
But being able to produce a bar chart or a circle histogram like that, a pie chart is, depends on being able to recognize the semantics of what you have combining.
So you have to combine things so you have to know that these things are the same type that you can count them, and they can add them together to produce a bar chart or pie chart.
So that means recognizing semantics underneath.
Entities you find.
OK, so those were some of the differences and there's more differences you can find in that article online.
So what enterprise search needs are?
Is this list of of five different things?
The first thing that.
Enterprise search has to deal with is being able to connect up to all the different data that's in the enterprise.
And this is something that the global search engine.
Does not necessarily have to recognize because they don't have to go in and deal drove down to every database possible.
Although many of the common databases like Medline are also indexed.
So every time Microsoft comes out with a new system like share point, you have to produce a connector that allows you to take information out of that.

Out of that an index it, so there's lots of work for an enterprise search doing with all the different formats of information because the purpose is to cover 100% of the information inside of a company.
So currently we have we do with more than 400 formats of information and different.
Sources that are either the web or databases, Lotus notes, etc.
So those are one of the costs that it takes to enter the search market and enterprise search market.
You have to have all this engineering done in order to get the info.
Nation.
OK, so that's one of the needs.
Continual need to have more connectors.
An recently just last week I saw that there was a.
A talk being given in the posters are now being stored more and more on Second life.

So if you have information that's useful to the outside world that's in Second life, that means you need a connect to some avatar that's going into second life and extracting information an putting into the format that can be indexed, indexed by your searching.
OK, the second thing that we need is more varied semantic typing.
So each type that you can recognize that you can recognize a person, organization, money, and dates.
Those are semantic dimensions, and those are facets and you can expose all that information so you can.
When someone types a query, you can expose the different types of information that can be used to separate the results into piles.
And there's a need for more and more of those types.
For example, there's a.
There's a need for other geographic dimensions, and these are things that people have been working on, but there's lots of types that people that are not quite mapped out as geography are.
For example, if you're dealing with restaurants, you want to know different menu types, you want to know what's Asian food or what's French food.

And each one of those is semantic dimensions, so that needs more natural language processing and more typing of things which can either be there was a discussion at lunch, whether the typing comes from manual tagging, or from the semantic web, some sort of organized structure an you need both.
OK, and then with each type you need emerging policy.
Have to know whether these types you can only list them or whether you can add them up or you have to count them and so there's different information for presenting the results of each type.
And then once.
Could be done.
You can make mashups here.
I'll show 3 examples.
This is a standard example of traditional search.
If you type in the French president's name, you get a list of results.

Now there's another company called every which types when you type in the French President name, it has mind a lot of the information inside of Wikipedia and so now represent the Wikipedia entry for the person you type, and it also is pumping information from news sources and it finds new sources with that.
That's not very novel, But the interesting thing is that there mashing together the information from Wikipedia, for example, since Sarkozy is known as a head of state.

But the middle part is dig deeper shows all the different facets and hear the piggybacking off of the facets in Wikipedia.
But there's a need for finding new facets automatically.
So the way we look at enterprise search is that information is coming from structured information like database records.
It's coming from the web from parts of the web that are specific to certain business or.

We're talking about a certain business, and our purpose is to give someone a factory which allows them to extract all this information and normalize it, and that normalized information compute presented in a mashup or to extend the database.

There's also all these Blogger entries that mention this thing, and there's information about the people sentiment about the restaurant, so this information comes from a wide variety of sources, and this is what where we think the future of not only enterprise search is going, but also web search in general.
